metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the main legal issues extracted from the document:
* Whether the applicant is a necessary or proper party in the present suit
* Infringement of intellectual property rights under the Customs Intellectual Property Rights (Imported Goods) Enforcement Rules, 2007
* Jurisdictional issue: whether the court can consider the import of goods by the defendant as a basis for infringement of the plaintiff's trademarks
* Right to seize and confiscate goods under Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962
* Effectiveness of Rule 11 of the Customs Rules in destruction of seized goods pending legal proceedings
* Interpretation of paragraph 2.3 of the Foreign Trade Policy, 2015-20 on importation of goods
* Whether the plaintiff's suit for injunction precludes the applicant from proceeding under the IPR Enforcement Rules during the pendency of the suit

* Scope of impleadment in the present suit and the rights of the plaintiff to choose parties against whom he wishes to litigate (in relation to Mumbai International Airport (P) Ltd. v. Regency Convention Centre & Hotels (P) Ltd.)
* Requirement for a "No-Objection Certificate" from the intellectual property right holder under Rule 11 of the Customs Rules
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary:**

This is a civil case No. CS(COMM) 835/2018 of Western Digital Technologies, Inc & Anr vs Syt Solutions Pvt. Ltd., wherein the present judgment has been delivered by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal on December 13th, 2022.

**Background:**

The plaintiff company had filed a suit against the defendant company, alleging infringement of their trademarks. The applicant in this case, Commissioner of Customs (General), Air Cargo Complex, Sahar, Andheri (East), Mumbai, sought to be impleaded as a proper party in this suit on the grounds of infringement of intellectual property rights under the Custom Intellectual Property Rights (Imported Goods) Enforcement Rules, 2007.

**Legal Issues:**

The main legal issue that arose was whether the applicant should be impleaded as a necessary or proper party to this suit. The applicant claimed that they had passed a seizure memo on goods imported by the defendant company under Section 110(1) of the Customs Act, 1962, which was in violation of the provisions of the Foreign Trade Policy.

**Arguments:**

The plaintiff argued that the applicant is not a necessary or proper party to this suit as it has been filed solely for trademark infringement and does not involve any proceedings related to customs. The defendant also opposed the application on similar grounds. On the other hand, the applicant claimed that they are entitled to be impleaded due to their interest in seeing the customs procedures followed.

**Court Findings:**

The court noted the tests laid down by the Supreme Court in Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal (2005) 6 SCC 733 for determining a necessary and proper party, which includes:

*   A person whose presence is necessary for deciding the rights of parties or whose interest may be affected.
*   The applicant must not merely claim an interest, but should demonstrate his direct association with the controversy.

Considering these guidelines, the court observed that there are two aspects of jurisdiction that need to be satisfied: (a) when all persons claimed as necessary or proper parties have been added; and, (b) whether all such parties have taken active participation in the proceedings.

**Arguments Rebuttal:**

The counsel for the applicants argued that the defendant's refusal to consent would not vitiate plaintiff's claim regarding impleadment of the applicant. They relied on the provision of Rule 11 of the Customs Rules which suggests that "if infringing goods have been confiscated and no legal proceedings are pending in relation to such goods, the applicant may proceed to destroy the goods after obtaining 'No-Objection Certificate' from the intellectual property right holder."

The counsel for the applicants argued that this shows they were prepared to comply with Rule 11 but needed the required cooperation and support of the IP Holders so as to ensure their duties are carried out under Section 110(1) of Customs Act. If IPR is not violated, the case will not require adjudication by a Court.

**Decision:**

However, in accordance with the Supreme Court's observation that "the general rule with regard to impleadment of parties is that the plaintiff in a suit, being dominus litis, may choose the persons against whom he wishes to litigate and cannot be compelled to sue a person against whom he does not seek any relief," as stated in Mumbai International Airport (P) Ltd. v. Regency Convention Centre & Hotels (P) Ltd., the Hon'ble Justice Amit Bansal dismissed the applicant's plea.

1. 
The present application has been filed on behalf of Commissioner of 
Customs (General), Air Cargo Complex, Sahar, Andheri (East), Mumbai – 
400009 seeking impleadment in the present suit as a proper party. 
2. 
The application is premised on the infringement of the intellectual 
property rights of the plaintiff in terms of the Custom Intellectual Property

--- PAGE 2 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 2 of 7 
 
Rights (Imported Goods) Enforcement Rules, 2007 (hereinafter referred to 
as „IPR Enforcement Rules‟), on account of the import of goods by the 
defendant. The applicant had passed a seizure memo dated 2nd May, 2018 in 
respect of 9,644pieces of the goods imported by the defendant under Section 
110(1) of the Customs Act, 1962. It is also the case of the applicant that 
goods which have been imported into India are in violation of paragraph 2.3 
of the Foreign Trade Policy, 2015-20 and are therefore, liable for 
confiscation under Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962. 
3. 
Both the plaintiff and the defendants have opposed the present 
application. Plaintiffs have filed reply in opposition to the aforesaid 
application, wherein it stated that the present suit has been filed on the basis 
of infringement of the plaintiffs‟ trademarks by the defendant and therefore, 
the applicant is neither a necessary and nor a proper party for the 
adjudication of the present suit. The applicant, vide its letter dated 24th April, 
2018, asked the plaintiff of its willingness to join the proceedings, failing 
which the applicant would release the seized goods. Rule 11 of the Customs 
Rules states that if the infringing goods have been confiscated and no legal 
proceedings are pending in relation to such goods, the applicant may 
proceed to destroy the goods after obtaining „No-Objection Certificate‟ from 
the intellectual property right holder. Since the plaintiff has chosen to file 
the present suit for injunction, the applicant cannot proceed under the IPR 
Enforcement Rules during the pendency of the present suit. Therefore, the 
applicant is neither a necessary party nor a proper party. 
4. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties. 
5. 
The 
Supreme 
Court 
in Mumbai 
International 
Airport 
(P) 
Ltd. v. Regency Convention Centre & Hotels (P) Ltd., (2010) 7 SCC 417, 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 3 of 7 
 
has observed that the general rule with regard to impleadment of parties is 
that the plaintiff in a suit, being dominus litis, may choose the persons 
against whom he wishes to litigate and cannot be compelled to sue a person 
against whom he does not seek any relief. 
6. 
In Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal, (2005) 6 SCC 733, the Supreme Court 
laid down the tests to determine as to who is a necessary party and proper 
party in a suit. The relevant portions are set out below: 
“7*.  In our view, a bare reading of this provision, namely, 
second part of Order 1 Rule 10 sub-rule (2) CPC would 
clearly show that the necessary parties in a suit for specific 
performance of a contract for sale are the parties to the 
contract or if they are dead, their legal representatives as also 
a person who had purchased the contracted property from the 
vendor. In equity as well as in law, the contract constitutes 
rights and also regulates the liabilities of the parties. A 
purchaser is a necessary party as he would be affected if he 
had purchased with or without notice of the contract, but a 
person who claims adversely to the claim of a vendor is, 
however, not a necessary party. From the above, it is now 
clear that two tests are to be satisfied for determining the 
question who is a necessary party. Tests are — (1) there must 
be a right to some relief against such party in respect of the 
controversies involved in the proceedings; (2) no effective 
decree can be passed in the absence of such party. 
… 
11. As noted hereinearlier, two tests are required to be 
satisfied to determine the question who is a necessary party, 
let us now consider who is a proper party in a suit for specific 
performance of a contract for sale. For deciding the question 
who is a proper party in a suit for specific performance the 
guiding principle is that the presence of such a party is 
necessary to adjudicate the controversies involved in the suit 
for specific performance of the contract for sale. Thus, the 
question is to be decided keeping in mind the scope of the 
suit. …” 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 4 of 7 
 
7. 
In Vidur Impex & Traders (P) Ltd. v. Tosh Apartments (P) Ltd., 
(2012) 8 SCC 384, the Supreme Court has succinctly laid down the 
principles to be followed while deciding an application filed under Order 1 
Rule 10(2) of the CPC. Paragraph 36 in this regard is set out below : 
“36. Though there is apparent conflict in the observations 
made in some of the aforementioned judgments, the broad 
principles which should govern disposal of an application for 
impleadment are : 
 
1. The court can, at any stage of the proceedings, either 
on an application made by the parties or otherwise, 
direct impleadment of any person as party, who ought 
to have been joined as plaintiff or defendant or whose 
presence before the court is necessary for effective and 
complete adjudication of the issues involved in the suit. 
 
2. A necessary party is the person who ought to be 
joined as party to the suit and in whose absence an 
effective decree cannot be passed by the court. 
 
3. A proper party is a person whose presence would 
enable the court to completely, effectively and 
properly adjudicate upon all matters and issues, 
though he may not be a person in favour of or against 
whom a decree is to be made. 
 
4. 4. If a person is not found to be a proper or necessary 
party, the court does not have the jurisdiction to order 
his impleadment against the wishes of the plaintiff.” 
 
8. 
At this stage, a reference may be made to the prayers made in the 
plaint, which are set out below: 
“A. A decree of permanent injunction restraining the 
defendants, their partners, representatives and/or others 
acting for and on their behalf for importing, selling, offering 
for sale, advertising or otherwise dealing in infringing goods 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 5 of 7 
 
bearing the plaintiffs’ registered trademarks WESTERN 
DIGITAL,
 and/or WD under nos.1345682, 1349235 and 
1325732 in Class 9. 
 
B. 
An order of delivery up of all the infringing goods 
bearing the plaintiffs’ trademarks WESTERN DIGITAL,
 
and/or WD including packaging(s), cartons, labels, stickers, 
and/or publicity material bearing the impugned trademarks for 
the purposes of destruction/erasure. 
 
C. 
An order for damages of Rs.1,00,01,000. 
 
9. 
As can be seen from the above, no relief has been sought against the 
applicant. The entire case of the plaintiff is based on the infringement of the 
trademarks of the plaintiffs by the defendant. Therefore, it cannot be said 
that an effective decree cannot be passed in the present suit in the absence of 
the applicant. It is not even the case of the applicant that the applicant is a 
necessary party, as the present application seeks impleadment only on the 
basis of the applicant being a proper party. 
10. 
In terms of the legal position discussed above, for a person to be a 
proper party to a suit, it is to be seen whether the presence of such person 
would enable the Court to completely, effectively and properly adjudicate 
upon the issue in the case. 
11. 
At this stage, a reference may be made to Rule 11 of the IPR 
Enforcement Rules, the relevant portion is set out below: 
“11. Disposal of  infringing goods. –  
 
(1) Where upon determination by the Deputy Commissioner 
of Customs or Assistant Commissioner of Customs, as the case 
may be, it is found that the goods detained or seized have 
infringed intellectual property rights, and have been 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 6 of 7 
 
confiscated under Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962 
and no legal proceedings are pending in relation to such 
determination, the Deputy Commissioner of Customs or 
Assistant Commissioner of Customs, as the case may be, shall 
destroy the goods under official supervision or dispose them 
outside the normal channels of commerce after obtaining “no 
objection” or concurrence of the right holder or his authorized 
representative. 
 
 
 
…” 
 
12. 
In terms of the aforesaid Rule, the applicant has the jurisdiction to 
determine if the seized goods are infringing the Intellectual Property Rights 
of the plaintiffs, only in the event of no legal proceedings being pending in 
relation to such determination. However, the present suit is such a legal 
proceeding in which a determination is to be made whether the goods 
imported by the defendant are infringing or not. Therefore, in terms of Rule 
11 of IPR Enforcement Rules, the applicant cannot go into the question of 
infringement till the final adjudication of the present suit. 
13. 
In the event, this Court comes to a finding that the defendant has not 
infringed the trademarks of the plaintiffs, the said determination shall be 
binding on the applicant and there cannot be any question of destruction of 
the infringing goods.  On the other hand, if a final determination is made by 
this Court that the goods have infringed the trademarks of the plaintiffs, 
appropriate orders shall be passed with regard to the aforesaid goods. 
14. 
In view of the discussion above, the applicant is neither a necessary 
party nor a proper party for the adjudication of the suit. There is no merit in 
the present application and the same is dismissed. 
15. 
Needless to state this is without prejudice to any other statutory 
rights/remedy of the applicant.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 7 of 7 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018 
16. 
In the order dated 5th July, 2019, the submission of the counsel for the 
plaintiff has been recorded that the present suit is a fit case for the Court to 
proceed to pass a summary judgment under Order 13A of the Code of Civil 
Procedure, 1908. 
17. 
In terms of the aforesaid order, both sides have filed their respective 
written submissions along with judgments in support thereof. 
18. 
List for hearing on 21st March, 2023. 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
DECEMBER 13, 2022 
dk 
 
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary**

The case is Western Digital Technologies, Inc & ANR vs Syt Solutions PVT. LTD., 2022/DHC/005588, decided on December 13, 2022.

**Parties:**

* Plaintiffs: Western Digital Technologies, Inc & ANR (represented by Mr. Prithvi Singh and Ms. Devyani Nath)
* Defendant: Syt Solutions PVT. LTD. (represented by Mr. Nakul Mohta, Advocate)
* Intervenor: Commissioner of Customs (General), Air Cargo Complex, Sahar, Andheri (East), Mumbai

**Facts:**

* The plaintiffs alleged infringement of their trademarks by the defendant.
* The commissioner of customs sought to implead themselves as a proper party in the suit, claiming infringement of intellectual property rights under the Custom Intellectual Property Rights Enforcement Rules, 2007.

**Arguments and Decision:**

* The plaintiffs opposed the application, arguing that the commissioner is neither a necessary nor a proper party.
* The Supreme Court's decision in Mumbai International Airport (P) Ltd v. Regency Convention Centre & Hotels (P) Ltd. was cited to support this argument.
* The Honorable Justice Amit Bansal decided not to admit the application, citing Rule 11 of the Customs Rules.

**Dates and Amounts:**

* May 2, 2018: secession memo dated
* April 24, 2018: letter from applicant to plaintiff relating their intention to release seized goods

Source:
PDF source: WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf in the section Case Header and Parties

**Case Summary**

Source: WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD (2022/DHC/005588) - CS(COMM) 835/2018

**Key Facts and Proceedings**

* The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi issues a judgment on December 13, 2022.
* Western Digital Technologies Inc. & Anr vs Syt Solutions Pvt Ltd is the subject matter of the suit (CS(COMM) 835/2018).
* Commissioner of Customs (General), Air Cargo Complex, Mumbai seeks impleadment as a proper party via I.A. 3096/2020.
* The application is filed to address infringement on Western Digital's intellectual property rights related to Custom Intellectual Property.

**Parties and Counsel**

* Plaintiffs: Western Digital Technologies Inc. & Anr (represented by Mr. Prithvi Singh and Ms. Devyani Nath, Advocates)
* Defendant: Syt Solutions Pvt Ltd (represented by Mr. Nakul Mohta, Advocate and Mr. Ajay Kumar Pandey, Senior Panel Counsel)

**Coram**

* Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal heard the application.

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary:
Based on Page 2 of the provided PDF (WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD), here is a summary of the legal facts, proceedings, arguments, decisions, dates, names, and amounts:

**Proceedings**: The Court is considering an application (I.A. No. 12048/2019) filed by the Applicant, Western Digital Technologies Inc.

**Background**: The Applicant seized goods worth Rs. 8,54,000 from the Defendant under Section 110(1) of the Customs Act, 1962.

**Arguments**: Both parties have opposed the application. The Plaintiff (Western Digital) argues that the Applicant is not a necessary party to the suit for trademark infringement. The Applicant claims that it cannot destroy the seized goods without the intellectual property right holder's consent or a No-Objection Certificate.

**Decisions**:

* The Suit was filed on April 24, 2018.
* The seizure memo was passed by the Applicant on May 2, 2018.
* The Plaintiff will not provide a No-Objection Certificate, citing pendency of the suit for injunction.

**Sources**: PDF source: WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD (2022/DHC/005588). Court File Number: CS(COMM) 835/2018

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of Section "Background and Facts" from the PDF "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf":

**Case Details**

* Case No: CS(COMM) 835/2018
* Date of decision: 13th December, 2022
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Parties involved**

* Plaintiffs: Western Digital Technologies Inc. and another (hereinafter referred to as "Western Digital")
* Other parties not explicitly mentioned in the section.

**Background**

The court begins by discussing the principle that a plaintiff, being dominus litis, has the discretion to choose against whom they wish to litigate.

**Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal case reference**

In this case, the Supreme Court laid down tests for determining necessary and proper parties in a suit:

* Necessary party: (1) the party must have a right to some relief against such party; (2) no effective decree can be passed without their presence.
* Proper party: The guiding principle is the necessity of adjudicating controversies involved in the suit.

**Condonation of delay**

Western Digital had applied for condonation of delay in re-filing an application, which was granted.

**Judicial observation**

The court observed that a person who claims adversely to the claim of the vendor is not a necessary party in a suit for specific performance of a contract.

This summary is under 300 words and focuses on legal proceedings, facts, arguments, decisions, parties, dates, and amounts from Section "Background and Facts".

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3 from the PDF:

**WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf**

The Delhi High Court case (2022/DHC/005588) discusses the concept of necessary and proper parties in a suit for specific performance of a contract.

Sixth paragraph (5) quotes from Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal, (2005) 6 SCC 733, stating that:

* A necessary party must have a right to some relief against another party in respect of the controversy involved.
* No effective decree can be passed without such a party's presence.

 Eleventh paragraph (11) further explains that two tests are required to determine a necessary party: (1) right to relief and (2) no decree possible without such party. 

The focus is on defining necessary and proper parties in a suit for specific performance of a contract for sale, setting out the legal framework as per Order 1 Rule 10 sub-rule (2) CPC.

**PDF Source:** WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf

CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 3 of 7 
 
has observed that the general rule with regard to impleadment of parties is 
that the plaintiff in a suit, being dominus litis, may choose the persons 
against whom he wishes to litigate and cannot be compelled to sue a person 
against whom he does not seek any relief. 
6. 
In Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal, (2005) 6 SCC 733, the Supreme Court 
laid down the tests to determine as to who is a necessary party and proper 
party in a suit. The relevant portions are set out below: 
“7*.  In our view, a bare reading of this provision, namely, 
second part of Order 1 Rule 10 sub-rule (2) CPC would 
clearly show that the necessary parties in a suit for specific 
performance of a contract for sale are the parties to the 
contract or if they are dead, their legal representatives as also 
a person who had purchased the contracted property from the 
vendor. In equity as well as in law, the contract constitutes 
rights and also regulates the liabilities of the parties. A 
purchaser is a necessary party as he would be affected if he 
had purchased with or without notice of the contract, but a 
person who claims adversely to the claim of a vendor is, 
however, not a necessary party. From the above, it is now 
clear that two tests are to be satisfied for determining the 
question who is a necessary party. Tests are — (1) there must 
be a right to some relief against such party in respect of the 
controversies involved in the proceedings; (2) no effective 
decree can be passed in the absence of such party. 
… 
11. As noted hereinearlier, two tests are required to be 
satisfied to determine the question who is a necessary party, 
let us now consider who is a proper party in a suit for specific 
performance of a contract for sale. For deciding the question 
who is a proper party in a suit for specific performance the 
guiding principle is that the presence of such a party is 
necessary to adjudicate the controversies involved in the suit 
for specific performance of the contract for sale. Thus, the 
question is to be decided keeping in mind the scope of the 
suit. …”

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Western Digital Technologies vs. Syt Solutions Pvt Ltd., Court Case: 2022/DHC/005588**

This legal document is a High Court of Delhi judgment from December 13, 2022, in case CS(COMM) 835/2018.

**Pertinent Facts and Arguments:**

* Western Digital Technologies (Plaintiff) filed a suit against Syt Solutions Pvt Ltd. for trademark infringement.
* The Plaintiff prayed for permanent injunction, delivery up of infringing goods, and damages of Rs.1,00,01,000.
* The case turned on whether the applicant, whose identity remains unknown from the text, is a proper party to be impleaded in the suit.

**Key Legal Arguments:**

The court relied on Vidur Impex & Traders (P) Ltd. v. Tosh Apartments (P) Ltd., 2012 SCC 384, which distinguished necessary parties, proper parties, and applicants who can be impleaded at any stage of proceedings.

* The Plaintiff did not seek relief against the applicant.
* The issue in question related to trademark infringement by the Defendant and not the Applicant, which led the court to rule that an effective decree could still be passed without impleading the Applicant as a necessary party (para 9).

**Decision:**

The Court ruled that, for someone to be considered a proper party, their presence would need to enable the court to "completely, effectively and properly adjudicate upon all matters and issues" in the case. As per Rule 11 of IPR Enforcement Rules, disposal of infringing goods is governed by Customs authorities. The Applicant's inclusion would not have affected the effective passage of an ordinance. Thus, the application for impleadment was rejected.

Source: WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf
tree_structure.pdf_source: 1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
Based on page 4 of the provided PDF (1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf), here is a summary of the legal facts:

**Case Details**

* Case: 2022/DHC/005588, CS(COMM) 835/2018
* Date of Decision: December 13th, 2022

**Supreme Court Ruling**

The Supreme Court laid down principles in Vidur Impex & Traders (P) Ltd. v. Tosh Apartments (P) Ltd., (2012) 8 SCC 384:

1. The court can direct impleadment of anyone who ought to be joined as a party.
2. A necessary party is one whose absence prevents an effective decree.
3. A proper party enables the court to completely adjudicate on matters and issues.
4. If someone is not a proper or necessary party, the court lacks jurisdiction to order their impleadment.

**Plaintiffs' Prayers**

The plaintiffs, Western Digital Technologies, Inc., and another, prayed for:

* A permanent injunction restraining defendants from importing, selling, or dealing in infringing goods.
nodes.content:
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 4 of 7 
 
7. 
In Vidur Impex & Traders (P) Ltd. v. Tosh Apartments (P) Ltd., 
(2012) 8 SCC 384, the Supreme Court has succinctly laid down the 
principles to be followed while deciding an application filed under Order 1 
Rule 10(2) of the CPC. Paragraph 36 in this regard is set out below : 
“36. Though there is apparent conflict in the observations 
made in some of the aforementioned judgments, the broad 
principles which should govern disposal of an application for 
impleadment are : 
 
1. The court can, at any stage of the proceedings, either 
on an application made by the parties or otherwise, 
direct impleadment of any person as party, who ought 
to have been joined as plaintiff or defendant or whose 
presence before the court is necessary for effective and 
complete adjudication of the issues involved in the suit. 
 
2. A necessary party is the person who ought to be 
joined as party to the suit and in whose absence an 
effective decree cannot be passed by the court. 
 
3. A proper party is a person whose presence would 
enable the court to completely, effectively and 
properly adjudicate upon all matters and issues, 
though he may not be a person in favour of or against 
whom a decree is to be made. 
 
4. 4. If a person is not found to be a proper or necessary 
party, the court does not have the jurisdiction to order 
his impleadment against the wishes of the plaintiff.” 
 
8. 
At this stage, a reference may be made to the prayers made in the 
plaint, which are set out below: 
“A. A decree of permanent injunction restraining the 
defendants, their partners, representatives and/or others 
acting for and on their behalf for importing, selling, offering 
for sale, advertising or otherwise dealing in infringing goods 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 5 from PDF: Western Digital Technologies vs Syt Solutions PVT LTD**

**Case:** CS(COMM) 835/2018, I.A. 12048/2019(O-XI R-1 of CPC), I.A. 12049/2019
**Date:** December 13, 2022 (Decision Date)
**Court:** High Court of Delhi

The plaintiffs demand relief against Syt Solutions PVT LTD for trademark infringement. The requested relief involves:

A. A permanent injunction to restrain the defendant from using infringing marks.
B. Delivery up and destruction/erasure of infringing goods bearing the plaintiff's trademarks.
C. Damages of Rs. 1,00,01,000.

The court rules that the applicant (Syt Solutions PVT LTD) must be impleaded as a proper party to ensure an effective decree can be passed in the suit.

**References:**

* Rule 11 of the IPR Enforcement Rules

**Source:** Page 5 of "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf" (2022/DHC/005588)
nodes.content:
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 5 of 7 
 
bearing the plaintiffs’ registered trademarks WESTERN 
DIGITAL,
 and/or WD under nos.1345682, 1349235 and 
1325732 in Class 9. 
 
B. 
An order of delivery up of all the infringing goods 
bearing the plaintiffs’ trademarks WESTERN DIGITAL,
 
and/or WD including packaging(s), cartons, labels, stickers, 
and/or publicity material bearing the impugned trademarks for 
the purposes of destruction/erasure. 
 
C. 
An order for damages of Rs.1,00,01,000. 
 
9. 
As can be seen from the above, no relief has been sought against the 
applicant. The entire case of the plaintiff is based on the infringement of the 
trademarks of the plaintiffs by the defendant. Therefore, it cannot be said 
that an effective decree cannot be passed in the present suit in the absence of 
the applicant. It is not even the case of the applicant that the applicant is a 
necessary party, as the present application seeks impleadment only on the 
basis of the applicant being a proper party. 
10. 
In terms of the legal position discussed above, for a person to be a 
proper party to a suit, it is to be seen whether the presence of such person 
would enable the Court to completely, effectively and properly adjudicate 
upon the issue in the case. 
11. 
At this stage, a reference may be made to Rule 11 of the IPR 
Enforcement Rules, the relevant portion is set out below: 
“11. Disposal of  infringing goods. –  
 
(1) Where upon determination by the Deputy Commissioner 
of Customs or Assistant Commissioner of Customs, as the case 
may be, it is found that the goods detained or seized have 
infringed intellectual property rights, and have been 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 6 from the PDF:

**Case Details:**

* Case No.: CS(COMM) 835/2018
* Application No.: I.A. 12048/2019 (O-XI R-1 of CPC)
* Date: December 13, 2022

**Legal Facts and Proceedings:**

* Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962 requires destruction of goods after determination by Deputy Commissioner of Customs or Assistant Commissioner of Customs.
* Rule 11 IPR Enforcement Rules restricts applicant's jurisdiction to determine if seized goods infringe Intellectual Property Rights when legal proceedings are pending.

**Arguments and Decisions:**

* The Court holds that the applicant cannot determine infringement until the final adjudication of the present suit.
* If the court finds no infringement, the determination shall be binding on the applicant, preventing destruction of goods.
* If the court determines infringement, appropriate orders will be passed regarding the goods.

**Dismissing Application:**

* The application is dismissed with no merit.
nodes.content:
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 6 of 7 
 
confiscated under Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962 
and no legal proceedings are pending in relation to such 
determination, the Deputy Commissioner of Customs or 
Assistant Commissioner of Customs, as the case may be, shall 
destroy the goods under official supervision or dispose them 
outside the normal channels of commerce after obtaining “no 
objection” or concurrence of the right holder or his authorized 
representative. 
 
 
 
…” 
 
12. 
In terms of the aforesaid Rule, the applicant has the jurisdiction to 
determine if the seized goods are infringing the Intellectual Property Rights 
of the plaintiffs, only in the event of no legal proceedings being pending in 
relation to such determination. However, the present suit is such a legal 
proceeding in which a determination is to be made whether the goods 
imported by the defendant are infringing or not. Therefore, in terms of Rule 
11 of IPR Enforcement Rules, the applicant cannot go into the question of 
infringement till the final adjudication of the present suit. 
13. 
In the event, this Court comes to a finding that the defendant has not 
infringed the trademarks of the plaintiffs, the said determination shall be 
binding on the applicant and there cannot be any question of destruction of 
the infringing goods.  On the other hand, if a final determination is made by 
this Court that the goods have infringed the trademarks of the plaintiffs, 
appropriate orders shall be passed with regard to the aforesaid goods. 
14. 
In view of the discussion above, the applicant is neither a necessary 
party nor a proper party for the adjudication of the suit. There is no merit in 
the present application and the same is dismissed. 
15. 
Needless to state this is without prejudice to any other statutory 
rights/remedy of the applicant.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
This is a court decision document from the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, dated December 13, 2022 (pdf: WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD). The case number is CS(COMM) 835/2018.

**Background:** The plaintiffs are Western Digital Technologies, Inc. and another party (named), while the defendant is Syt Solutions Pvt Ltd.

**Court Decision:** The court has ordered a hearing to decide on a summary judgment under Order 13A of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. Both parties have filed written submissions with accompanying judgments in support of their arguments.

**Important Dates and Timeline:**

* July 5, 2019: Court order recording plaintiff's submission to proceed with a summary judgment.
* March 21, 2023: List for hearing scheduled.
* December 13, 2022 (dated): The court decision is made by Justice Amit Bansal.

**Key Information:**

* Case type: Commercial Suit (COMM)No. CS(COMM) 835/2018
* Application numbers: IA 12048/2019 and IA 12049/2019.
* Specific amounts or orders are not mentioned in the summary section provided.

**Summary:** The High Court of Delhi has scheduled a hearing to consider a summary judgment in the case of Western Digital Technologies vs. Syt Solutions Pvt Ltd, allowing both parties to present their written submissions and supporting judgments.
